column1: Newport Beach is a coastal city in Orange County
column2: California
column3: United States. Newport Beach is known for good surfing and sandy beaches. Newport Harbor once supported maritime industries but today it is used mostly for recreation. Balboa Island draws visitors with a waterfront path easy access from the ferry to the shops and restaurants. Its population was 85
column4: 287 at the 2010 census.

column1: The Upper Bay of Newport is a canyon
column2: which was carved by a stream in the Pleistocene period. The Lower Bay of Newport was formed much later by sand that was brought along by ocean currents
column3: which constructed the offshore beach that is now recognized as the Balboa Peninsula of Newport Beach.

column1: Before settlers reached the coasts of California
column2: the Newport area and surrounding areas were very prominent Indian lands. Indian shells and relics can still be found today scattered throughout the area. Though
column4: settlers began to settle the area due to the availability of land. The State of California sold acre-plots of land for $1 a piece in the Newport area. Anglo-American inhabitation in the area grew substantially following the events of 1870 when a 105-ton steamer named The Vaquero
column5: captained by Captain Samuel S. Dunnells (against warnings posted by surveyors) safely steered through the lower and upper bay of Newport where it unloaded its cargo. James Irvine
column7: quickly traveled from his home in San Francisco to the San Joaquin Ranch. Meeting in Irvine's ranch house near current day UC Irvine with his brother
column10: they all agreed that the newly found port should be named simply
column11: "Newport" thus where Newport Beach gets its name. James McFadden built a long McFadden Wharf in 1888.In 1905
column12: city development increased when Pacific Electric Railway established a southern terminus in Newport connecting the beach with downtown Los Angeles. In 1906 (with a population of 206 citizens)
column13: the scattered settlements were incorporated as the City of Newport Beach.Settlements filled in on the Peninsula
column16: Balboa Island and Lido Isle. In 1923 Corona del Mar was annexed and in 2002 Newport Coast
column17: East Santa Ana Heights and San Joaquin Hills
column19: after a long battle with the city of Costa Mesa
column20: Newport Beach annexed West Santa Ana Heights.

column1: Newport Bay is divided by the Pacific Coast Highway bridge
column2: which is too low for most sailboats and very large boats to pass under. North of the bridge is referred to as Upper Newport Bay
column3: or the Back Bay. South of the bridge is commonly called Lower Newport Bay
column4: or Newport Harbor. However the Back Bay also has harbor facilities
column5: especially the marina and launch ramp at Newport Dunes Marina.The north end of the Newport Harbor channels around Lido Island have a number of small business centers and were at one time used by the fishing fleets as their home. On the North East side of the channel
column6: the Lido Marina Village now provides the local port to many "Newport Party Boats" as well as small merchants and local restaurants. It also hosts the area boat show each year as well as an organic "Farmers Market" Sundays
column7: in addition to being the port for the local Gondola Company. In 2014
column8: the center was closed for a renovation.In 1927 a home was built at the mouth of the entrance of Newport Harbor that came to be known as the China House of China Cove. The home was built using the traditional Chinese architecture. It was a landmark in the Newport Beach Harbor until it was demolished in the 1980s. Some of the original roof can be seen on a home located in the China Cove.Upper Newport Bay is an estuary that was formed by a prehistoric flow of the Santa Ana River. Today it is fed by a small stream from San Diego Creek. Much of Upper Newport Bay is a protected natural area known as the Upper Newport Bay Ecological Reserve

column1: Newport Beach has a mid-latitude semi-arid climate (Köppen climate classification BSk) with characteristics of a warm-summer Mediterranean climate (Köppen: Csb). Like many coastal cities in Los Angeles and Orange counties
column2: Newport Beach exhibits weak temperature variation
column4: compared to inland cities even a few miles from the ocean. The Pacific Ocean greatly moderates Newport Beach's climate by warming winter temperatures and cooling summer temperatures. Diurnal temperature variation is stronger during the winter than during the summer. Newport Beach does not receive enough precipitation to qualify as a true Mediterranean climate.

column1: The City of Newport Beach was incorporated on September 1
column2: 1906 and adopted its charter on January 7
column3: 1955. The city implements a council–manager form of government
column4: directed by a seven-member council who reside in specific geographic districts
column5: but are elected at-large.  Council elections take place in even-numbered years
column6: and councilmembers serve four-year terms.  The mayor is chosen annually by the city council.Until 1927
column7: the governing body of the City was known as a Board of Trustees with a President as its head. An act of the Legislature in 1927 changed the Board to City Council with a Mayor as the head.

column1: The Newport Beach Fire Department is the agency that provides fire protection
column2: lifeguard coverage

column1: Newport Beach has 8 fire stations spread across the city
column2: as well as Lifeguard Headquarters at the base of the Newport Pier.

column1: The Marine Division of the NBFD is responsible for lifeguarding the nearly 10 million annual visitors to Newport Beach's 6.2 miles (10.0 km) of ocean and 2.5 miles (4.0 km) of bay beaches. In 2013 alone the marine division performed 3
column2: 811 water rescues. Newport Beach Lifeguards are recognized as the top agency in the nation
column3: considering their relatively small size. They are also recognized as an advanced agency by the United States Lifesaving Association.

column1: Newport Beach Lifeguards also hold an annual summer Junior Lifeguard program
column2: which is one of the largest and oldest in the nation. The Junior Lifeguard program works closely with the John Wayne Cancer Foundation to spread skin cancer awareness.

column1: Included in their area is The Wedge
column2: a spot located at the extreme east end of the Balboa Peninsula that is known for its large wedge shaped waves that makes it a popular spot for skimboarding
column4: bodyboarding and bodysurfing.  During a south or south/southwest swell of the right size and aligned in the swell window
column5: the Wedge can produce huge waves up to 30 feet (9.1 m) high. Newport Beach has one of the most diverse coastlines in the world
column6: spanning over 6 miles. And because of this the NBFD Marine Operations Division requires Lifeguards to be in top shape and have years of local ocean experience to be able to work as an Ocean Lifeguard.

column1: Beachgoers have flocked to Newport Beach since the Pacific Electric Railway started bringing them in 1905. Attractions include the city beaches from the Santa Ana River to the tip of the Balboa Peninsula
column2: Corona del Mar State Beach
column3: and the beaches at Crystal Cove State Park. Newport Beach is known for good surfing
column4: especially between Newport Pier and the Santa Ana River. At the tip of the Balboa Peninsula
column5: The Wedge offers world-class bodyboarding and bodysurfing. Newport Pier and Balboa Pier draw fishermen and sightseers. A boardwalk runs 2.9 miles (4.7 km) from 36th Street in West Newport
column6: past Newport Pier and Balboa Pier
column7: to between E and F Streets on the Balboa Peninsula for both pedestrians and bikers.

column1: Newport Harbor is the largest recreational boat harbor on the U.S. west coast
column2: and a popular destination for all boating activities
column4: fishing
column7: and paddleboarding.The annual Christmas Boat Parade started in 1908. The New York Times has called it
column8: "One of the top ten holiday happenings in the nation".Competitive sailing
column10: and paddling events are common. The annual Newport to Ensenada International Yacht Race is the largest sailboat race in the world.Boating activities are organized by five private yacht clubs
column16: and water activity bases on the harbor. The Newport Aquatic Center allows open public participation in competitive rowing
column19: and outrigger canoe racing.  The Orange Coast College School of Sailing and Seamanship offers recreational and professional sailing and mariners' courses and certifications
column20: including United States Coast Guard licensing. Weekly races take place during the summer including the Beer Can Races.

column2: the historic Balboa Pavilion and Balboa Island Ferry are the city's most famous landmarks. Adjacent to the Pavilion
column3: the 500 passenger Catalina Flyer provides daily transportation to and from Avalon
column4: located on Santa Catalina Island. The Balboa Fun Zone is also home to the Newport Harbor Nautical Museum.Balboa Island village draws many visitors. A waterfront path around the island attracts walkers and joggers
column5: and provides easy access from the ferry to the shops and restaurants.

column2: or the Back Bay
column3: is ringed by Back Bay Drive and a network of trails and paths that attract bicyclists
column4: rollerbladers
column6: and walkers. Bird watchers and nature lovers are drawn to the Upper Newport Bay Ecological Reserve and Peter and Mary Muth Interpretive Center; and to Crystal Cove State Park
column7: which features tide pools at the beach
column8: and backcountry hiking and mountain biking trails. Camping is available at Crystal Cove State Park
column9: and at the Newport Dunes Waterfront Resort and Marina. Whale watching is also popular
column10: with both scheduled and charter boats leaving from Newport Harbor. Whales and dolphin can often be seen from the pier and shoreline during migration season.

column1: Fishing is also extremely popular in Newport Bay
column2: off the coast of Newport
column3: and along the Newport Bay Jetty. In the bay there are multiple locations to purchase bait for dockside or spear fishing convenience. There are about 80 fishable species located in Newport Bay. A few of the most commonly fished species are: Gray Smoothhound Shark
column4: Leopard Shark
column20: and Red Shiner. Commercial fishing is also prominent in offshore Newport Beach and Newport Bay. Lobsters are fished in the reefs.

column2: intense occurrences of bioluminescence can be observed when waves splash into the shore
column3: or when marine animals leave glowing traces in their wake.

column1: The boardwalk is a natural draw for bicyclists. Beach cruiser bikes can be rented at several places on the Balboa Peninsula. Bicyclists are also drawn to Back Bay Drive and the bike paths around Upper Newport Bay; the hilly roads winding through Newport Coast and the San Joaquin Hills; and the mountain biking trails in the San Joaquin Hills and Crystal Cove State Park. Pacific Coast Highway provides access to these areas and is a major bicycle route through the region
column2: despite being shared with heavy motor vehicle traffic.

column1: Many neighborhoods in Newport Beach are amenable to bicycling. Locals are inclined to use bicycles for short trips
column2: especially to get through summer beach traffic and avoid motor vehicle parking shortages.

column1: The Pelican Hill area has two golf courses that rank among the Golf Digest America's 100 Greatest Public Golf Courses.
Fashion Island at Newport Center is a regional shopping and entertainment destination. Also at Newport Center
column2: the Orange County Museum of Art exhibits modern and contemporary art
column3: with emphasis on the work of Californian artists.Dining in Newport Beach
column4: like many oceanfront towns
column5: tends to focus on seafood restaurants but there are a variety of restaurants that range in price and type of food.

column1: Newport Beach has two farmers' markets: Saturday mornings in Corona Del Mar and Sunday mornings in Lido Village.
